docs.title: 🛡️ Welcome to Encrypted Wiki
docs.text: This is my personal knowledge base dedicated to Offensive Programming, Cybersecurity Research, and Tool Development. This wiki serves as a living document for everything I learn and build.

docs.title: 🚀 Explore the Wiki
docs.text: You can navigate through the different sections using the sidebar or start with these core topics:

docs.title: 🐍 Python for Cybersecurity
docs.text: Learn how to leverage Python for system-level interactions and automation: * Introduction to OS Module: Mastering file system manipulation.

docs.title: 💻 Offensive Programming
docs.text: A deep dive into writing code from an attacker's perspective to better understand security flaws.

docs.title: 🛠️ Features
docs.text:
1. Global Search: Press F or use the search bar at the top to find specific commands or notes instantly.
  2. Interactive Code: All code blocks come with a "Copy to Clipboard" button for quick testing.
  3. Dark/Light Mode: Switch between themes using the icon in the header for a comfortable reading experience.

Disclaimer: The content provided here is for educational and ethical research purposes only.

Last updated: {{ git_revision_date }}

docs.title: Introduction to structure of C program
docs.text:
The C programming structure follows a well-structured manner, much like a recipe for cooking a meal. Just as a recipe has a specific order—listing ingredients before you start cooking.

A C program needs a specific structure so the computer knows how to read and run it. By organizing the code into six distinct parts, you ensure that the "tools" and "ingredients" are ready before the "cooking" begins.

Using this structure makes your code neat and helps you find mistakes easily because everything has its own designated place.

docs.title: Definitions of Preprocessor Headers:
docs.text:
The preprocessor headers are placed at the very top of a C program. These are libraries that contain functions—or tools—that you can use in your program.

Think of these libraries like toolboxes owned by a carpenter. A toolbox contains tools like a hammer or nails. When the carpenter needs to fix something, they do not have to recreate or redesign the hammer from scratch; they simply grab it from the box. They don't have to "reinvent the wheel"—they just include the boxes they need.

docs.title: Breaking down the syntax:
docs.text:
When you see a line like this:

#include <stdio.h>

There are three important parts to understand:

  • The # symbol: This is a "pre-instruction." It tells the computer to prepare these tools before it starts reading your main code.
  • The < > brackets: These tell the computer to look in the "standard" storage area where the built-in C toolboxes are kept.
  • The .h extension: This stands for Header. It is like an index or a manual at the top of the toolbox that lists all the tools inside.

Example: The Printing Tool

For example, there is a tool in C used to print or display messages on the screen. This tool (called printf) lives inside a toolbox called stdio.h (which stands for Standard Input/Output). To use this tool, you must tell the computer to "include" that toolbox at the very top of your file so the computer knows where to find it.

docs.title: The definition of main function:
docs.text:
The main function is the starting point of the program. Think of it like the front door of a building. When you enter a building, you have to look for the front door; without it, you can't enter and do whatever you want to do.

Similarly, in a C program structure, the computer or the compiler looks for a specific name to know where the "instructions" begin. This starting point is a function called main. Without it, the computer doesn't know which line of code to run first.

Every C program must have this function because this is where the compiler starts. Imagine a building without a front door—how can anyone enter?

docs.title: The general syntax of the main function:
docs.text:
The general syntax of the main function is:

int main() {
  /* The instructions of the program here. */

  return 0;
}

docs.title: The components of the main function:
The name of the function main():
docs.text: When you write the main function, you use the keyword main and the brackets. While the computer will not throw a syntax error if you add a space, the common practice is writing them without a space between them: main().

docs.title: The return value type int:
docs.text:
You might notice the word int before main and the return 0; at the end. This tells the computer that when the program finishes, it will send back a number (an integer).

In C, every function usually tells the computer what kind of "answer" or "result" it will give back. The word int is short for integer (a whole number).

By putting int before main, you are making a promise to the computer. You are saying: "When this program finishes its job, I promise to give you back a whole number.

docs.title: The return statement inside the function:
docs.text: The return 0; statement is like a "mission accomplished" signal. By sending the number 0 back to the computer, the program says, "Everything finished correctly without any problems.

docs.title: Introuction to variables in C programming
What is the line-orinted command interpretor:
docs.text:
A command interpreter is a program that: -Prints a prompt (like >>> or myapp> ). -Waits for you to type a line of text. -Runs some code based on that line. -Then loops back to the prompt again. ​

This is what cmd gives you: a ready‑made loop that: -Shows a prompt. -Reads a line. -Parses it into a command name and arguments. -Calls the right method on your class. -Repeats until you tell it to stop. ​ So cmd is not the shell itself; it’s the engine that drives an interactive line‑oriented shell.

docs.title: An overview of the REPL loop concept:
docs.text:
Before you touch the cmd module, you must understand the REPL (Read–Eval–Print Loop).

In standard programming, a script runs from the top line to the bottom line and then stops. To build a tool that feels like a real "app," the program must not stop. It must enter a Loop.

Think of a loop like a guard at a gate. The guard does not go home after the first person walks through. The guard waits, asks for a "command" or "ID," processes it, and then goes back to waiting. This is called a Read-Eval-Print Loop (REPL).

Every interactive program—from your Python shell to a Linux terminal—runs on this fundamental cycle:

  • Read: The program pauses and waits for you to type something.
  • Eval (Evaluate): The program takes that text and determines what it means.
  • Print: The program displays the result.
  • Loop: The program returns to Step 1 and waits again.

The cmd module automates this loop so you don't have to write it yourself. But if you don't understand that your program is now "trapped" in a circle, you will never control it.

In Python’s cmd module, this loop is handled by a method called cmdloop(). Without this loop, a program runs once and terminates. With it, you create an interactive environment.

For example:

If you want to write a simple or primitive Python interactive shell following the REPL concept, you can use a while loop combined with try–except blocks.

while True:
    try:
        user_input = input("ENTER COMMAND > ")
        user_input_clean = user_input.strip().lower() 
        if user_input_clean  == "hello":
            print("Hi, there!")
        elif user_input_clean  == "status":
            print("System is running.")
        elif user_input_clean == "exit":
            break
        else:
            print("Unknown command")

    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        print("\nShutdown signaled")
        break

In the previous example, the line that asks the user to enter or provide input represents the READ phase. In this phase, the computer only reads whatever the user enters.

user_input = input("ENTER COMMAND > ")

In the EVAL phase, the computer evaluates the user input. It takes whatever the user enters, interprets its meaning, and checks whether it matches the program’s logic.

In the Eval phase, the danger isn't just "doing an action." The danger is untrusted input. If your evaluation logic is weak, a user could enter something that crashes the process, leaks data, or bypasses security. You are the gatekeeper; if your logic is flawed, the "gate" is useless.

The following lines represent the EVAL phase:

if user_input.strip().lower() == "hello":
elif user_input.strip().lower() == "status":
elif user_input.strip().lower() == "exit":

In the PRINT phase, the program outputs a response based on the evaluated input. The following lines represent the PRINT phase:

print("Hi, there!")
print("System is running.")
print("Unknown command")
print("\nShutdown signaled")

In the LOOP phase, the program returns to the beginning and waits for new input. This phase is represented by the infinite loop itself:

while True:

As long as no break statement is triggered, the program continues cycling through READ → EVAL → PRINT → LOOP, which is exactly what defines a REPL-based interactive program.

docs.title: Importing the cmd module:
docs.text:
First, if we want to use all the contents of the cmd module, we have to import it first to be able to access its content:

import cmd

docs.title: Creating a custom class child that inherits from the parent class (cmd.Cmd):
docs.text:
After importing the cmd module, there is a class called cmd.Cmd. This class is a very important class inside the cmd module. It knows how to loop, how to handle help menus, and how to find commands.

So, we create a child class from the parent class and inherit from the parent all the powers it has. After creating the child class that inherits from the parent class, you can define the specific commands you want.

The general syntax is:

import cmd

class subclass_name(cmd.Cmd):
    # write the commands here

When you write class MyShell(cmd.Cmd):, you are telling Python: "Give MyShell all the powers of cmd.Cmd, but I will add my own flavor to it."

docs.title: Defining all the methods or commands inside the subclass:
Defining the command dispatcher:
docs.text:
Defining all the methods or commands inside the subclass means you are telling your program what actions it should take when a user types a specific command in your shell. Each command is written as a method inside your custom class that inherits from cmd.Cmd.

The naming convention is important: each command method must start with do_ followed by the name of the command. For example, if you want the command to be hello, you define a method called do_hello.

Inside the method, you write the instructions for what should happen when the user types that command. The method can also take an argument, usually called arg, which holds any extra text the user types after the command. This allows your commands to accept input dynamically, so they are not limited to fixed actions.

The cmd module always gives your command one raw string as the argument and does not split it automatically. The reason is that a space character does not always mean a new argument. Sometimes a space is just part of the same text.The module cannot guess the user’s intention.

Think of the cmd module as a very polite receptionist. It listens carefully, writes down exactly what you said, and refuses to guess your intentions.

When you type a command in a cmd.Cmd shell, everything after the command name is handed to your method as one raw string (arg). No splitting. No interpretation. Just the text.

For example:

If the user writes:

note This is my long note

What the command really needs is this single value:

arg = "This is my long note"

If cmd split the argument automatically, it would become:

["This", "is", "my", "long", "note"]
Now the program has a problem.Were those five separate arguments? Or was the user trying to write one note containing spaces?

The cmd module cannot know that safely.It cannot guess the intention of the user.

If the tool automatically treats spaces as separators, it is making an assumption about what the user meant. The cmd module avoids this mistake by passing the input as a raw string and letting the command itself decide how to interpret it. That way, the program stays correct instead of guessing.

So the program passing yhe raw string:

"This is a long note"
it avoids making a wrong assumption. The command author—not the framework—decides how to interpret the text.

This design gives you freedom:

-You can treat the whole string as one value (notes, messages, SQL queries, search text).

-You can split it yourself if your command truly expects multiple arguments.

-You can implement quoting rules, flags, or custom parsing later.

For example:

import cmd

class SimpleShell(cmd.Cmd):
    def do_hello(self, arg):
        print("Hi from the module!")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    SimpleShell().cmdloop()

Explanation of the example:

  • do_hello is a command that the user can type in the shell.
  • arg contains any text the user types after the command.
  • cmdloop() starts the interactive loop where the user can type commands repeatedly.

Example-1: 

import cmd

class SimpleShell(cmd.Cmd):
    def do_greet(self, arg):
        if arg:
            print(f"Hello, {arg}")
        else:
            print("Hello, stranger")
if __name__ == "__main__":
    SimpleShell().cmdloop()

Example-2: 

class StatusShell(cmd.Cmd):
   def do_status(self, arg):
       if arg:
           print("Your status is {arg}")
       else:
           print("Your status is missing!")

if __name__ == "__main__"
   StatusShell().cmdloop()

Here’s the same idea, cleaned up and explained plainly, without changing the meaning—just tightening the logic and fixing one small naming slip.

When a user types a command like status online into a program built with Python’s cmd module, the module first looks at the first word. That first word is treated as the command name. In this case, the command is status.

The cmd module then checks whether a method named do_status exists on your command class. If that method exists, the module knows that status is a valid command and that do_status is the method that should handle it.

Everything after the command name is treated as one raw string. Here, the remaining text is online, so the module passes that exact string as the argument. As a result, it calls:

do_status(self, "online")

The important detail is that the argument is not split for you. Even if there were multiple words after status, they would still arrive as a single string.

So when a user types status online, the process is simple: the module identifies status as the command, identifies online as the argument string, and calls do_status(self, "online").

If the user types only status with no extra text, the module still calls the same method, but this time it passes an empty string:

do_status(self, "")

An empty string is still a string, which means your command method is always called with exactly one argument, whether the user typed extra text or not. This design keeps command handling predictable and puts you, not the framework, in control of how arguments are interpreted.

docs.title: What is print function and what is the syntax ?
docs.text: The print() function is a function that can be used to print whatever you add inside it to the screen. If you want to display information on the screen or to make the system show it, you can use the print() function. The print() function takes text, variables, or whatever you want to print to the screen.

docs.title: The general syntax of print() function:
docs.text:
The general syntax of the print() function is:

 print("Write any text here")
or

 print('Write any text here')

docs.title: What is the purpose of quotation marks?
docs.text:
Quotation marks tell the computer to treat what is inside them as text, which we call a "string." This is different from a variable, which is a name for a piece of data, or a value, like a number.

If you leave out the quotation marks, the computer will try to find a variable with the name you typed. Since you haven't defined any variables yet, the computer won't know what to do. It will get confused and show an error called a NameError, because it thinks you are referring to something that doesn’t exist.

For example:

print(I LOVE PROGRAMMING)

In this case, the user forgot to put quotation marks around the text they want to print. The computer will try to look for variables named I or LOVE, but since none exist, it will panic and throw a SyntaxError.

This line:

print(I Love programming)

is invalid Python syntax. Python sees I and Love as variable names, not text, because there are no quotation marks around them. Since you haven’t defined variables called I or Love, Python gets confused.

That’s why it throws a SyntaxError. It also suggests maybe you forgot a comma, because it sees multiple “words” without proper separation.

The correct way to print text is to enclose it in quotes:

print("I Love programming")

This tells Python: “Treat this exactly as text (a string), don’t look for variables.”

Output:

I Love programming

Without the quotes, Python can’t interpret your intent—it only understands text when you wrap it in quotation marks.

We only can't use the quotation marks only if we want to display or print a number value or a variable that contains a value stored inside it.

For example:

secret_code = 123456789
print(secret_code)

Output: 

123456789

When I print(secret_code), I do not use quotation marks. Why? Because I want the computer to look inside the box and print what is there. If I wrote print("secret_code"), the computer would literally print the words "secret_code" instead of the address.

docs.title: Types of quotation marks:
docs.text: You can use double quotations or single quotations. It depends on what is inside the function.

docs.title: Case 1:
docs.text:
If the text you want to print contains a single quote, then you have to use double quotes "".

 print("Write any 'text' here")

Example1:

Imagine you are trying to bypass a security gate. To get through, you need to make the system display a specific phrase on the screen.The phrase is:

System's Online
If you try to write print ('System's Online') , the computer gets confused because it thinks the message ends at the letter m.

So to solve this conflict, we have to use the double quotation mark which will act like a container. This container holds all the text including the single quotation mark, so the computer does not get confused about where the message starts or ends.

Because the double quotes are on the outside, the single quote inside is treated as just a normal character instead of a command. This makes sure the code runs correctly and displays the full sentence on the screen without any errors or conflicts.

print("System's Online")

docs.title: Case 2:
docs.text:
If the text you want to print on the screen contains double quotes, then you have to use single quotes only so they do not conflict.

So to solve this conflict we have to use the double quotation mark which will act like a container the contain all the text including the single quotation mark.

 print('Write any "text" here')

docs.title: The general syntax of the lists:
Introduction to Exception Handling
docs.text: Here's the corrected version with spelling, grammar, and formatting issues fixed while preserving the original structure, wording, and intent:

docs.title: What are types of error in Python:
docs.text: The errors in Python can be categorized into more than two types of errors, but we will focus here on two types only.

docs.title: Definition of syntax errors:
docs.text:
Syntax errors are the errors that occur when the programmer writes bad code. The code is like a sentence in the English language with broken grammar. As we know,

For example, if you tell someone in your conversation a sentence like this: "jkhfldhfhfkljhfjkldf" then the second person in your conversation or the one you communicate with will not understand you and as a result will not perform or do what you need because the sentence isn't grammatically correct.

Instead, if you tell him something like this "Give me your phone," the second person then will understand you well because the sentence is grammatically correct, following the grammar rules.

The programming language is the language that the computer and the programmers can understandand use to communicate with each other.

Similarly, when the programmer writes code that is broken or not understandable, then the computer will not understand what the programmer needs and the computer cannot even start the program because it doesn't understand the rules or the broken language. So the errors which occur because of invalid syntax are called syntax errors.

For example: Imagine you are writing a Python script to scan a network port and inside your code you write this snippet of code:

print("Scanning the port 80"

In this snippet of code, the Python interpreter sees that there is a ) missing and as a result the Python interpreter refuses to start and run the program completely.

Example-1:

my_grade = 170
if my_grade < 80
   print("You are good.")
elif my_grade >100:
   print you are excellent.
Output: 
SyntaxError: invalid syntax

In this example, there are two syntax errors. The first one in the if statement—you were missing the colon :. And the second syntax error occurred because you didn't write the print function syntax well. So to solve these errors and make the program execute normally, you have to write this:

my_grade = 170
if my_grade < 80:
   print("You are good.")
elif my_grade >100:
   print("you are excellent.")

Output: 

you are excellent.

The programmer is responsible for correcting these syntax errors. Once all syntax errors are corrected, then only program execution will be started.

docs.title: Definition of runtime errors:
docs.text:
Runtime errors are the errors that occur during the run time of the program. They are not errors in grammar rules of the language but errors that appear or occur after the execution of the program.

These types of errors don't prevent the program from execution, but the termination of the program is abnormal. Such types of errors are called exceptions and cause the program to terminate abnormally unless handled.

docs.title: Why is an Exception more "dangerous" during a live hack than a Syntax Error?
docs.text:
The exceptions can be considered more dangerous than the syntax error in term of security because in the syntax errors the errors occur before the execution of the program so that the programmer can easily discover it and solve it. And the program never runs because it doesn't understand the bad syntax and no sensitive data leaks to attackers.

but in the runtime errors or exception the error occurs after the exceution of the program and can exposes sensitive information to the attackers.When an exception occurs, Python automatically prints detailed error messages to help programmers debug.

These messages often include sensitive information like full file paths on the server, database names, or even parts of secret configuration files.

For example: Imagine a program that can't find a file called /app/configs/secret_db_credentials.json. The error message will show this exact path to anyone watching - including a hacker. Now they know exactly where your secret database passwords are stored and the structure of your server folders.

In a live hack situation, attackers deliberately trigger these exceptions by sending bad data. Each crash reveals more about your system's internals through the stack trace (which shows function names and code flow). Syntax errors can't be triggered this way since the program never runs, but exceptions create a constant leak of valuable attack information during the active hack.

A stack trace is like a breadcrumb trail showing exactly which functions your program called right before it crashed. When your Python program runs into an exception during a live hack, it automatically prints this stack trace. Think of your code as a chain of dominoes falling one after another—function A calls function B, which calls function C, and so on. The stack trace lists them all in order, starting from the very last function that caused the problem and working backward to where your program began.For example, if you see something like this in an error:

FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/app/configs/secret_db_credentials.json'
  File "main.py", line 45, in load_config
    with open(config_path) as f:
  File "server.py", line 123, in start_server
    config = load_config()
  File "app.py", line 10, in <module>
    start_server()

This tells the hacker: "Your secret file is at /app/configs/secret_db_credentials.json, the load_config() function is on line 45 of main.py, and it was called from start_server() on line 123 of server.py." Suddenly they know your exact file structure, function names, and code locations—information a hacker can use to attack deeper into your system. Syntax errors never how this because the program never even starts running.

docs.title: Types of Program Execution Flow
docs.text: There are two paths that any program can follow when it runs.

docs.title: Normal Flow of Program Execution in Python
docs.text:
The normal flow of program execution, as the name suggests, means the program executes from the first line to the end correctly without showing any errors. In a program, if all statements execute successfully according to their conditions and produce the expected output, then that flow is called the normal flow of program execution.

For example: 

x = 10
y = 20
z = x + y
print(f"The result is: {z}")
The above program executes successfully from start to end and produces the expected output.

Output: 

The result is: 30
The program's execution flow is normal; no errors appear, and it terminates correctly with the expected output.

docs.title: Abnormal Flow of Program Execution in Python
docs.text:
While executing statements in a program, if any error occurs at runtime, the program flow terminates abnormally immediately, without executing the remaining statements. This kind of termination is called an abnormal flow of execution. The following example terminates abnormally.

For example: 

x = 10
y = 20
z = x + y
print(f"The sum is: {z/0}")
print(f"The average is: {z/2}")
The above program does not execute successfully or produce output.

Output: 

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 4, in <module>
ZeroDivisionError: division by zero
The program's execution flow is abnormal; a runtime error (Division by zero) appears, and it does not terminate normally or produce the expected output. The program terminates in the middle of execution where the runtime error occurs. As discussed, if a runtime error occurs, it won't execute the remaining statements, so the last print function does not execute.

docs.title: Definition of IndexError:
docs.text:
The IndexError, as the name suggests, it is the error that is related to the index, and when we say index, we are pointing out all the data structures that depend on indexes to accessing or editing the data structure elements like the list, tuple, dictionaries, and even the string.

This error occurs when you are trying to access an element in these data structures that doesn't exist there. If you are trying to access an element in a sequence such as (lists, tuples, dictionaries, string) using an index outside their valid range.

This error typically occurs when the index exceeds the sequence's length, such as trying to access my_list[5] on a list with only three elements (indices 0, 1, 2). Negative indices that go beyond the start also trigger it, like my_list[-4] on a short list. It can also happen during loops where the index calculation overshoots.

Example-1: You have a list of 3 target IP addresses, but you tell your script to attack the 10th one.

target_list = ["192.168.1.3", "192.168.2.45", "192.168.2.60"]

print(f"Attacking the target :{target_list[10]}")

This will throw an IndexError because the script is trying to access the 10th element regardless that the length of the target list is only 3.

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "script.py", line X, in <module>
   print(f"Attacking the target :{target_list[10]}")
IndexError: list index out of range

Example-2 You are using a script to extract a password from a list of stolen credentials. Look at the code below:

stolen_passwords = ["admin123", "password!", "qwerty"]
# We want to see the 5th password in the list
target_password = stolen_passwords[4]
print(target_password)

Output:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "script.py", line X, in <module>
    target_password = stolen_passwords[4]
IndexError: list index out of range

This script will throw an IndexError exception because the script is trying to access the 5th password in the stolen_passwords list, but this index is out of range or outside the range of the list because the length of the list is 3, not 5 or more. By asking for index 4, you are reaching into empty space. The program crashes because it cannot find data that doesn't exist.

docs.title: What is f-string method and how to use it?
docs.text:
Before writing any academic explanation of the f-string method, we have to explore the purpose of this method and why do we need to use it. Assume you are writing a script to log your progress on a system. You want the screen to show a message like:

Scanning port 80

This text is a combination of a piece of text (as a string) that is "Scanning Port " and an integer variable which represents the number of the port being scanned. This number is an integer variable which cannot be hardcoded and is not a constant; it would be, in some cases, 80, 334, 21, etc.

So, how can we combine a piece of text or a string with a variable?

The f-string method is used to solve this problem. I can easily combine a string with a variable in one option. To do this, you need to combine a piece of text (a string) with your variable.

docs.title: The general syntax of f-strings:
docs.text:
In modern Python, the easiest way to put a variable inside a sentence is using an f-string. You put an f before the first quote and put your variable name inside curly brackets {}.

variable1 = value1
print(f"Any piece of text with {variable1}")

The curly brackets {} inside the string make the content inside them act as a variable, not a string. It will be replaced with the value of the variable inside the curly bracket.

For example:

If we have a variable called target_port and it has a value of 80:

target_port = 80

And we want to print or display the value of the variable in a text, we should write:

print(f"Scanning Port {target_port}")

This will print:

Scanning Port 80

As we see, the text contains the value of the variable, which is 80, not the name of the variable, which is "target_port".

Example-1:

target = "Server-A"
print(f"Attacking {target}")

This will display:

Attacking Server-A

Would you like me to create a small challenge for you to practice using f-strings with multiple variables?

docs.title: Different use cases of f-strings method:
Case 1: Combining string with a single variable:
Case 3: Doing Math inside the Brackets
What is integer validation and why do we need it?
docs.text:
In Python programming, we always ask the user to provide information that will be manipulated inside the script. The problem is that a programmer must never trust the intention of the user. This is one of the most important rules in programming: do not trust user input.

The user can enter inputs that cause the program to crash, and attackers can intentionally trigger these crashes to access sensitive information. They force the program to fail by entering invalid inputs.

Because of that, we need to validate user input correctly to avoid such issues. User input validation can be categorized into many types depending on what you want to validate and what you expect the user to enter.

Integer validation means being completely sure that the user enters a whole number, not a float, string, or boolean value.

In the real world, hackers often use tools to scan a network for open ports. A port is like a numbered door on a computer. These numbers are always whole numbers (integers), such as 80 or 443.

When you write a script to scan a port, you must make sure the user provides a whole number. If the user types "ABC" instead of "80", the program will crash.

In Python, we use the input() function to get data, but it always returns text (a string). We then use int() to try to convert that text into a whole number.

For Example:

If you want to build a basic port scanner, you need to ask the user which port number they want to scan.

target_port = int(input("Enter the port number: "))

Output:

Enter the port number:

The script will wait for the user input. Whatever the user enters will be stored as a string value, so we then try to convert it into an integer using the int() method.

After the user enters their input, many cases can happen. In security, we call this attack surface analysis.

Possible cases:

Case 1: The user entered a valid port number (0–65535)

If the user enters a valid value, for example 80, the input() function stores it as a string "80". Then int() successfully converts it into the integer 80 and stores it in the variable target_port.

The program runs normally, and no errors occur.

Case 2: The user entered a string value such as "EIGHTY"

If the user enters "EIGHTY", the input() function stores it as a string. When int() tries to convert this value, Python cannot convert non-numeric text into an integer.

This will cause a ValueError, and the program will crash if the input is not validated.

Case 3: The user entered a negative value such as -80

If the user enters -80, int() will successfully convert it into an integer because -80 is still a valid integer value in Python.

However, this value is invalid in the context of port numbers, because port numbers cannot be negative. If this case is not handled, the program logic becomes incorrect even though no exception is raised.

int(-80) works in Python because of how the int() function and the integer type are defined:

  1. int() converts strings or numbers into Python integers. Python integers (int) can be negative, zero, or positive. There is no restriction on sign.

  2. When you do:

x = int("-80")

-Python sees the string "-80" -The - sign is part of the numeric literal -int() parses it and produces the integer -80

  1. From Python’s point of view, -80 is a perfectly valid integer, so no error occurs.

The reason this is important in your context (ports) is that just because Python allows it doesn’t mean it’s semantically valid. Port numbers cannot be negative in networking, so you need to check for that after converting with int():

if target_port < 0 or target_port > 65535:
    print("Invalid port number!")

So, int(-80) works because Python’s integers are signed, but -80 is invalid for your specific use case.

Case 4: The user entered a string with a sign such as "+80"

If the user enters "+80", Python can successfully convert it using int() because +80 is a valid integer representation.

This means no error will occur, and the value will become 80. Even though this input works, it should still be considered during validation because it is a user-controlled input.

Case 5: The user entered a port number greater than the maximum allowed value

If the user enters a number greater than the maximum port value (65535), int() will still convert it successfully.

However, this value is invalid from a networking perspective, because valid port numbers must be between 0 and 65535.

If this case is not checked, the program may behave incorrectly or attempt operations that make no sense.

Case 6: The user entered an empty input or only spaces

If the user presses Enter without typing anything, or enters only spaces, input() stores it as an empty string. Trying to convert it with int() will cause a ValueError, crashing the program if not handled.

Case 7: The user entered a float value such as 80.5

If the user enters 80.5, int() cannot directly convert it unless explicitly cast or rounded. This will also cause a ValueError, and the program will crash without proper validation.

Case 8: The user entered special characters or symbols such as @80 or #123

Any non-numeric characters combined with numbers will cause int() to fail, raising a ValueError. Attackers can use this to test for input vulnerabilities.

Case 9: The user entered a very large number beyond Python’s integer limit (rare in Python 3 but theoretically possible if using other systems)

Python 3 handles arbitrarily large integers, but in some applications or libraries, extremely large numbers may cause overflows or unexpected behavior. Port numbers beyond 65535 are invalid in networking terms, even if Python accepts them as integers.

docs.title: Types of Integer validation:
docs.text: In Python programming, validating user input is essential to ensure the program runs safely and correctly. Depending on what you expect from the user, integer validation can take different forms. Here are the main types:

docs.title: 1. Validate that the user enters a positive integer (whole number):
The checks that we usually include:
docs.text:
This validation ensures that the user provides non-negative integers only (0 or greater). In this validation case, we ask the user to enter a positive integer only. Then we will convert the user input into an integer using int(), and also verify that the integer is greater than or equal to zero (>= 0).

- Step 1: Ask the user to enter a positive integer value using input() method:

user_input = input("Please enter a positive integer value: ")

- Step 2: Convert the user input into an integer using the int() method

This method will convert the string user input into an integer:

target_value = int(user_input)
  • Case 1: If the value converts successfully, store it in the variable.
  • Case 2: If the value does not convert successfully, Python will raise an exception. This exception needs to be handled, and the user should be asked again to enter a valid positive integer.

- Step 3: Ensure that the user value is greater than or equal to zero

if target_value >= 0:
    print("You entered a positive integer.")
else:
    print("You didn't enter a positive integer.")

- Step 4: Repeat the previous checks using a loop

We have to continuously recheck the input until the user enters a valid positive integer. This ensures that the program does not crash and only accepts correct input. The general approach:

  • Wrap Steps 1–3 in a loop
  • Catch exceptions when conversion fails
  • Reask the user to enter the value until it passes all checks
while True:
    try:
        user_input = input("Please enter a positive integer value: ")
        target_value = int(user_input)
        if target_value >= 0:
            print("You entered a positive integer.")
            break  # exit the loop once input is valid
        else:
            print("You didn't enter a positive integer. Try again.")
    except ValueError:
        print("Invalid input. Please enter a numeric positive integer.")

docs.title: Application of this check:
docs.text: Used for port numbers, quantities, ages, or any input that cannot be negative. Ensures invalid negative inputs or non-numeric inputs are rejected, and the program continues to run safely without crashing.

docs.title: 2. Validate that the user enters a negative integer
docs.text:
This validation ensures that the user provides integers less than zero.

Checks usually include:

  • Convert the input to an integer using int()
  • Verify that the integer is less than zero (< 0)

Application of this check:

Used for error codes, offsets, or cases where only negative numbers are meaningful.

3. Validate that the user enters any integer (positive, negative, or zero) and not a string

This is the most general type of integer validation. It ensures the input is numeric and can include all integers, regardless of sign.

Checks usually include:

  • Attempt to convert the input to an integer using int()
  • Catch ValueError exceptions if the conversion fails (for example, if the user enters "abc" or "12.5")
  • Optionally, check for limits or constraints depending on the application

Application of this check:

Used when the program accepts all integers, such as counters, general numeric input, or configuration values. Ensures strings or floats are rejected.

4. Validate that the user enters a non-zero integer

This validation ensures the user provides an integer that is not zero.

Checks usually include:

  • Convert the input to int()
  • Verify that int(input) != 0

Application of this check:

Used for divisors in calculations, configuration offsets, or any scenario where zero is invalid.

5. Validate that the user enters an even or odd integer

This validation ensures that the integer satisfies a parity condition.

Checks usually include:

  • Convert the input to int()
  • For even: int(input) % 2 == 0
  • For odd: int(input) % 2 != 0

Application of this check:

Used for alternating sequences, even-numbered IDs, or other parity-specific requirements.

6. Validate that the user enters an integer divisible by a step (modular integer)

This validation ensures the input is a multiple of a specific step or interval.

Checks usually include:

  • Convert the input to int()
  • Verify that int(input) % step == 0

Application of this check:

Used for multiples of 5, even port ranges, or any scenario requiring fixed-step increments.

7. Validate that the user enters a strictly formatted integer (no extra characters)

This validation ensures the input contains only digits, with an optional leading + or -.

Checks usually include:

  • Use a regular expression like ^[+-]?\d+$
  • Convert to int() only if it matches

Application of this check:

Prevents inputs like "12abc", "12.0", or " 80 " from passing validation. Useful for secure input parsing.

8. Validate that the user enters a custom domain integer

This validation ensures the input is one of a predefined set of integers.

Checks usually include:

  • Convert input to int()
  • Verify that int(input) in allowed_values

Application of this check:

Used for menu options, choice numbers, or any input that must match a specific allowed list.

docs.title: What is Variables in Python Porgoramming?
docs.text:
Variables in Python can be seen as a box where you keep your important items, like toys or other things. You can also think of them as a container that holds water. In the hacking world, variables are very important. They are used to save helpful data so you can use it later.

For example:

For example, if I am looking into a suspicious server, I need a place to store that server's IP address. This allows me to use that address again for different tasks later on.

Instead of writing this down on paper, we will use Python to create a "box" (a Variable) to store this address in the computer's memory. This allows your hacking tools to use that address automatically later.In Python, we name the box first, then use the = sign to put something inside it.

server_ip = "192.168.1.1"

Because an IP address contains dots and numbers, Python sees it as "text" (a String). You must put the address inside quotation marks, like this: "192.168.1.5"

docs.title: What is os module?
docs.text:
os module is a python module which contains a lot of functions and attributes that help python scripts to interact directly with Operating system.os module acts as a bridge between the OS and the python scripts because the python scripts can't interact directly with the Operating systems.

Operating systems can manipulate the file system and the memory and the CPU while the python script is a blind code that can live only in it's own memory.What is outside the memory the python script can not interact with so it comes the role or the importance of the os module.

Think of the computer as a big house full of rooms and details. The Python script is like a guest staying in this house. The operating system is the house manager who controls everything.The guest can't go around the house alone or touch things directly. He needs the house manager to guide him and carry out his requests. The Python script works the same way—it needs the house manager (OS) to access the house (hardware and resources).

The os module is like the special protocol or rules the guest uses to talk to the house manager. It's an interface or API. So the process goes: Python script (guest) → os module (protocol) → operating system (house manager) → hardware (house).No matter what kind of house it is, the os module gives the Python script a consistent way to ask the house manager for help across different operating systems.

It allows your program to perform tasks that you would normally do manually, such as creating folders, renaming files, or checking which operating system you are using

docs.title: Why Python needs the os module?
docs.text: We need the os module for three reasons.

docs.title: 1- Abstraction:
docs.text:
The os module hides the complexity of the operating system operations. Think of it like when you are in a restaurant and want to ask for a meal. You don't need to know how the oven works or how to cut the meat; you just tell the waiter (the os module) what you want.

For example:

Imagine you want to write a Python tool that works on both Windows and Linux and must:

  • Create a directory for logs.
  • Write files into that directory.
  • Read an environment variable (like an API key).

Without the os module, you have to write very complex code related to the operating system to create a directory for logs, write files into that directory, and then read an environment variable (like an API key). All these operations you can do easily using a terminal or file explorer, but performing all of these operations in a Python script without the os module is a very, very complex process.

If Python didn't have the os module, you would have to learn the deep, "scary" internal code of Windows AND Linux AND Mac just to save a simple text file. The os module acts as a unified interface. You give one simple command to Python, and the os module translates it into the "secret language" of whatever computer you are using.

docs.title: 2- Portability:
docs.text:
The os module makes Python code portable, which means this code can run normally on different operating systems because the os module is a translator between your Python code and the operating system. You write a single line of code that can be executed on different operating systems; you don't need to write code especially for each operating system. So the code will be agnostic code or cross-platform code. Think of it like this: you can go to a restaurant in London or a restaurant in Tokyo. The "menu" (the Python commands) stays the same, even if the "kitchen" (the OS) works differently in each city.

By using the os module, you are writing code that is "future-proof." If a new operating system is invented tomorrow, and Python supports it, your script will likely work there without you changing a single line of your own logic.

docs.title: Importing the os module:
docs.text:
To import this module inside the python file you write this:

import os

You write import os at the top of your Python file. Now you can use all os tools.When you write import os, Python does NOT copy all content into your file. That's too big and slow!

Python looks in special folders (like lib or site-packages) and loads the os module into memory. Now you can use os.function().

docs.title: Navigating the current working directory:
docs.text:
Imagine the computer is a big house. If you want to navigate in the computer, you have to know your current location or you want to know where are you right now? Because this would be the starting point that you will use to navigate through the house.

So to know where are you right now? There is a tool (a function) that can be used to get your current working directory of the directory that you are standing in:

os.getcwd()

get: It means fetch or grabs the information cwd: it stands for the current working directory

This is a function that takes no arguments. It used with empty parentheses only—no arguments needed to use it. Think of it like asking someone, "Where am I?". You don't need to give them any extra information for them to tell you your own location. In Python, you just write it with empty parentheses:

os.getcwd()

It doesn't need to "take" anything because its only job is to "give" you the current address.

This function is "portable," which means it works exactly the same way on all kinds of computers—no matter if you're using Windows (like on a regular PC), Linux (common on servers), or Mac (Apple computers).

You type os.getcwd() with the exact same spelling and format every single time. Your code doesn't need to change at all when you move it from one computer to another. That's what makes it portable—it "travels" easily between different systems without breaking.

Even though you write the command the same way everywhere, the answer you get back will look a bit different because each operating system has its own special rules for showing folder paths:

System Example of what os.getcwd() returns:

Windows Linux/Mac C:\Users\Documents\MyProject (Uses backslashes \) /home/user/documents/myproject (Uses forward slashes /)

So, the os module acts like a smart translator. You speak "Python" to it, and it goes behind the scenes to talk to Windows or Linux in their own languages to get the answer for you.

docs.title: How to use it?
docs.text:
If you want to change your directory or your current directory there is a tool or a fuction that can do this job this tool is:

os.chdir( )

where:

  • ch : stands for change to change the currrent working directory

  • dir: is stands for the directory a fancy name for folder.

To use this tool you have to determine the new path or new address you want to move your program focus on it.It moves the focus (the eye) of the program, not the files of the program themselves.

Let's use the "Flashlight" Analogy: 🔦

  • Imagine your computer is a dark warehouse full of shelves (folders).

  • Your Python script is a person standing in that warehouse holding a flashlight.

  • Where the flashlight is pointing is the Current Working Directory.

  • When you run os.chdir(), you are telling the person to walk to a different aisle.

  • The person (the script) moves their body and their light to the new aisle, but they did not move the boxes on the shelves.

In technical terms: The .py file (your code) stays exactly where you saved it on the hard drive.The "Focus" (the point of view) of the running program changes.This is matter because If your code is sitting in Folder_A, but you use os.chdir('Folder_B'), your program is now "looking" inside Folder_B.If you try to open a file that is sitting right next to your script in Folder_A, the program will say "I can't find it!" because its "flashlight" is now pointing at Folder_B.

This function take one input or one parameter which is the path or the address of the new directory you want to move your program's focus to it.You must put the path (the address) inside the parentheses as a string (inside single quotes ' ' or double quotes " " ).

os.chdir("Path")

or

os.chdir('path')

The output of this function will be nothing after you run this command, the computer won't print anything.It just moves silently. To verify you actually moved, you would need to call os.getcwd() again.

Example: 

import os

#1. Check where we are first
print("Starting at:", os.getcwd())
#2. Command the program to move to a specific folder
os.chdir('C:/Users/Documents/MyProject')
#3. Check again to see the new location
print("Now I am at:", os.getcwd())

Notes:

  • A Common "Trap" for Beginners: When you use Windows, paths often look like this: C:\Users\Documents. In Python, the backslash () is a "special character." If you try to use it in os.chdir(), Python might get confused.

Two ways to stay safe:

Use Forward Slashes: Just use / instead of . Python is smart enough to fix it for you. 

os.chdir('C:/Users/Documents')

The "Raw" String: Put an r before your quotes. This tells Python: "Treat this text exactly as it is, no special characters." 

os.chdir(r'C:\Users\Documents')

  • Using the relative path and absolute path:

You can use the relative path and the aboslute path inside this function.imagine you want to move to a folder that is inside your current room. For example, you are in Documents and you want to enter a folder called Photos.Instead of typing the whole long address (C:/Users/Documents/Photos), you can just type the name of the folder: 

os.chdir('Photos')

docs.title: What is the purpose of this tool or function?
docs.text:
If we can just use Absolute Paths (the full address) to find any file, why bother "moving" the program at all?Here are the three main reasons why programmers use os.chdir():

1. It makes your code "Cleaner" and "Shorter" ✍️

Imagine you have 10 files in a folder called:

C:/Users/John/Documents/Year_2024/Projects/Python/Data_Files/
  • Without chdir: Every time you want to open a file, you have to type that giant address:
open('C:/Users/John/Documents/Year_2024/Projects/Python/Data_Files/file1.txt')
  • With chdir: You move there once, and then you just type the short name: 
    os.chdir('C:/Users/John/Documents/Year_2024/Projects/Python/Data_Files/')
open('file1.txt')

It saves you from typing (and making typos!) in long addresses.

2. Working with "Batches" of Files 📦 :

If you have a folder full of 100 photos and you want to rename all of them, it is much easier to "step inside" that folder first. Once you are inside, you can tell Python: "Look at everything here and add 'Fixed_' to the name." It is easier for the program to work on "what is right in front of it."

3. Using Shared Tools 🛠️:

Sometimes, you might download a script or a tool that only works if it is running inside a specific folder (because it looks for its own settings or images in the "current room"). By using os.chdir(), you can bring your program's focus to that tool's folder so it can run correctly.

A Simple Life Example:

Think of your computer like a Kitchen.

  • The Absolute Path way: You stand in the hallway and reach your long arm all the way into the cupboard to grab a plate, then reach all the way to the fridge to grab an egg. It's exhausting!
  • The os.chdir() way: You walk into the kitchen. Now, the plates, the fridge, and the stove are all "Relative" to you. Everything is within easy reach.

docs.title: What is os.listdir( ) function?
docs.text:
The os.listdir() is a function inside the os module that can be used to list the content of a folder. It tells you what files or folders are sitting inside that folder. If you want to explore the content of a specific folder/directory, then this tool will enable you to do so. When you use os.listdir(), you are asking Python to look at a folder and give you a list of names for everything sitting inside it.

There are some important facts about this function you have to take into consideration:

  • The function returns a list of strings:

This function only returns a list of the folder's content as strings, such as:

['notes.txt', 'Photos', 'Budget.xlsx']
  • It is shallow:

It is shallow" means it doesn't dig deep.It only shows you what is in the immediate folder. If there is a folder named Photos, it will tell you the folder exists, but it won't show you the pictures inside Photos yet.

Think of os.listdir() like peeking into a single drawer. It shows you everything sitting right there on top—like files and folders. But if one of those things is another drawer (like your "Photos" folder), it just says "Hey, there's a drawer here" without opening it to show the photos inside.

For Example: 

os.listdir('.')  # Shows: ['Photos', 'notes.txt']
# But NOT the images inside Photos!

This keeps it simple and fast—no automatic deep dive into subfolders.

  • The order of the content:

The names aren't always in alphabetical order; they usually appear in the order the computer stores them.os.listdir() gives folder names in the order the computer saves them on the disk. This order is not always A to Z. It can be different each time.

For example:

# It might show:
['Budget.xlsx', 'notes.txt', 'Photos']

# Or this on another computer:
['Photos', 'notes.txt', 'Budget.xlsx']

To get A to Z order, use sorted(os.listdir('folder')).

docs.title: How to use it?
docs.text: You have two simple ways to use os.listdir().

docs.title: Way 1: Check your current folder
docs.text:
If you don't put anything inside the parentheses (), it looks at the folder where your Python code is running right now.This checks the folder where your Python script is running. No path needed—just empty parentheses.

For example:

Say your script is in a folder called MyProject with these files: script.py, data.csv, images/.

import os

content = os.listdir()  # Empty = current folder

print(content)

# Output: ['script.py', 'data.csv', 'images']

What happens step-by-step: 1. Python looks where your script lives. 2. Lists all files/folders there. 3. Returns them as a list of names.

docs.title: Way 2: Check a different folder (detailed examples)
docs.text:
You can look inside any other folder without changing your position. Just give it the folder's path (like an address). Give a path to any folder. Use forward slashes / (works on Windows/Mac/Linux) or double backslashes \\ on Windows.

Example A: Relative path (near your current folder)

import os

content = os.listdir('images')  # Folder inside current one

print(content)

# Output: ['photo1.jpg', 'photo2.png']

Example B: Absolute path (full address from disk root)

import os

music_list = os.listdir('C:/Users/YourName/Music')  # Windows

# Or: music_list = os.listdir('/home/user/Music')  # Linux/Mac

print(music_list)
# Output: ['song1.mp3', 'playlist.m3u', 'Albums']

Example C: Handling errors

import os

try:
    files = os.listdir('nonexistent_folder')
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("Folder not found!")

Notes:

  • Paths can be strings like 'folder/' or '../parent_folder'.
  • Always import os first.
  • Returns list of strings (filenames only, no full paths).Since os.listdir() only gives you a list of text strings, the computer doesn't "know" if a name is a file or a folder just by looking at the list.

docs.title: Creating new directories:
docs.text: There are two ways to create new directories :

docs.title: Creating a single directory in the current location:
docs.text:
If you want to create a single folder in your current folder you can use this function:

 os.mkdir("FolderName")
where:

  • mk stands for make ro create or make new folder.
  • dir: stands for directory

This function only take the name of the new directory as a string using single quote (' ') or double quote (" ").

For example:

If You want to create a folder called "Photos" inside your current location.you write:

 os.mkdir("Photos")

Notes:

  • It only works if the "parent" folder already exists. If you try to create Movies/Action/Batman and the Movies folder doesn't exist yet, it will crash with an error.

  • If you run os.mkdir('photos') and the folder already exists, Python will crash and show an error called: FileExistsError: [Errno 17] File exists: 'photos'.It’s like trying to build a room where a wall already stands; the computer doesn't want to accidentally overwrite or mess up what is already there.To prevent your program from crashing, you should always "Ask before you Act." We use the tool we talked about earlier: os.path.exists().

    import os

folder_name = 'photos'

#1. Ask: Does this folder already exist?
if not os.path.exists(folder_name):
    # 2. If it does NOT exist, create it
    os.mkdir(folder_name)
    print("Folder created successfully!")
else:
    # 3. If it DOES exist, just give a friendly message
    print("The folder is already there, no need to create it.")

docs.title: Creating a single directory in different location:
docs.text:
You are not limited to the "room" you are standing in. You can build a folder anywhere in the house as long as you have the address (the path).Instead of just giving the name of the folder to os.mkdir(), you give it the Path of where you want that folder to be.

**For example:

import os
# Creating a folder in a completely different location
os.mkdir('C:/Users/Documents/New_Project')

Just like in real life, you can only build a room if:

  1. The path exists: You can't build a room in a house that hasn't been built yet. (The parent folder must exist).

  2. You have permission: You can't build a room in your neighbor's house! Some parts of the computer (like system folders) are "locked," and Python will give you a PermissionError if you try to create something there.

docs.title: Way 2 Creating multi folders (folders inside folders):
docs.text:
The problem with using os.mkdir() to create multiple folders at once is that if you try to build Year_2024/Summer/Photos all at once using mkdir, Python will look for Year_2024, and if it doesn't see it, it crashes.

It cannot build the "middle" parts for you. So os.mkdir() is used only to build one room at a time—like if you want to create a folder called Photos, and your current location is the Documents folder, this function will work perfectly without throwing any errors.

So this is where os.makedirs() comes in. It is like a smart builder that builds the entire path even if the middle folders are missing.

Example: Imagine your current folder is totally empty. You want to create this structure: 

Project/Data/2024`

If you use: 

`os.makedirs("Project/Data/2024")`

Python will:

  • Look for Project. It's not there? It builds it.

  • Look for Data inside Project. It's not there? It builds it.

  • Look for 2024 inside Data. It's not there? It builds it.

docs.title: Renaming directories:
docs.text: There also two way to rename directories:

docs.title: Renaming a directory in current location:
docs.text:
If you want to rename a folder found in the current working directory we can use the function 

os.rename("old_name", "new_name")

This tool needs two pieces of information (parameters):

  1. The Old Name: What it is called now.

  2. The New Name: What you want it to be called.

For example:

import os

# Let's rename our folder from 'photos' to 'Images'
os.rename('photos', 'Images')

# Let's rename a file from 'draft.txt' to 'final_report.txt'
os.rename('draft.txt', 'final_report.txt')

A Word of Caution ⚠️

os.rename() changes a file's name. The problem happens when the new name already exists in that folder. Python might stop with an error. Or worse, it might delete the old file with that name and replace it without telling you.

Always check if the new name is free before using os.rename(). This keeps your files safe.

Example:

You have a file called photo.jpg. You want to rename it to vacation.jpg. First check:

`import os
 if not os.path.exists("vacation.jpg"):  
    os.rename("photo.jpg", "vacation.jpg") 
    print("Renamed safely!") 
 else:  
    print("That name already exists!")`

This way, you never lose files by accident.

docs.title: Renaming a directory in a different location:
docs.text:
You can rename any folder, even if it's not in your current folder. Just use its full path (like a complete address) for both old and new names.

os.rename() needs two things—the old full path and the new full path. Python finds the folder and gives it the new name.

For example: Your current folder is Documents. You want to rename C:/Music/OldSongs to C:/Music/NewHits.

python

import os 
os.rename("C:/Music/OldSongs", "C:/Music/NewHits")
print("Folder renamed!")

What happens:

  • Python goes to C:/Music/.

  • Finds OldSongs folder.

  • Changes its name to NewHits.

  • Everything inside stays the same.

Another example (relative path): If you're in C:/Projects and want to rename a sibling folder:

import os 
os.rename("../Music/OldSongs", "../Music/NewHits")

This works anywhere—the full path tells Python exactly where to look.

docs.title: Identifying the Operating system type using os.name :
What is os.name?
docs.text:
System information identity means knowing the identity of the system run on the computer. The first information is knowing the operating system run on the machine or knowing whether the operating system is Windows, Linux or Mac OS. Knowing the type of operating system is the first thing anyone should know before dealing or interacting with the system because each operating system has its own rules for paths and files. For example if I want to reach a specific file in the machine I have to know its address in the realm of computer we call it the path but the rules of the paths are different and OS-specific. The path in Windows is different from the path in Linux and Mac each one has its own rules of formatting.

Imagine you are a ghost inside a computer. You want to open a door, but you don't know if you are in a house (Windows) or a castle (Linux). Every OS has its own "language" and its own rules for paths and files.The os module is your translator. It tells your Python code exactly where it is and who it is talking to. Without it, your code is "blind" to the world outside the Python interpreter.

To identify the operating system that runs on the system, we use a constant string attribute. It isn't a function; we don't put brackets ( ) after it, but it is a constant string attribute. 

os.name

In the world of objects, a function like os.getcwd( ) is a method or an action. It goes and "does" work to find the answer. An attribute (like os.name) is just a piece of data sitting in memory. It is a variable that the os module already filled with information when you imported it. When you run import os, the module checks the system immediately. It stores the result in a variable named name.

  • If you are on Windows, os.name will always be 'nt'.
  • If you are on Linux, Mac, or Unix, os.name will be 'posix'.

docs.title: Typical Values of os.name
docs.text:
3.2.1 'posix'

3.2.1.2 macOS and other Unix-like systems

docs.title: Security and os.name :
docs.text:
4.4.1 Path sanitization strategies per OS

4.4.2 Preventing path traversal with OS-aware checks

4.4.3 Permissions and privilege logic based on OS family

docs.title: What is a file and what are the differences between a file and a folder?
Removing files in the current directory:
Removing an existing and non-locked file in the current directory :
docs.text:
If you try to use os.remove() on a folder, Python usually throws an OSError or a PermissionError. Basically, it's Python saying, "Wait! This is a room (folder), not a piece of paper (file). I don't have the right tool for this!"

For example:

docs.title: Removing a non-existing file:
docs.text:
If you try to use os.remove("fileName") for a file that does not exist, Python will immediately stop your program and show a specific error.On most computers, you will see an error called FileNotFoundError. It looks something like this: FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'fileName'.Python does this because it wants to be sure you aren't making a mistake. It is saying: "You asked me to delete something, but I can't find it!".

As we saw with creating folders, the best way to handle this is to check before you delete.You can use os.path.exists() to make sure the file is there before you try to remove it.

For example:

import os

filename = "test.txt"

# 1. Check if it's actually there
if os.path.exists(filename):
    # 2. It exists, so it's safe to delete
    os.remove(filename)
    print("File deleted successfully!")
else:
    # 3. It's not there, so we just print a message instead of crashing
    print("The file was already gone, no action taken.")

docs.title: Removing a locked file :
docs.text:
The locked file is the file that is currently open or currently in use or open in another program such as (Word, Excel). In this case, your Python script doesn't have any permission to delete that file because it is currently preserved by another program. This is normal and happens in Windows or any operating system—imagine you want to delete a file that you currently have open; the operating system will show you a message telling you to close this file before removing it.

When your Python script tries to delete this locked file, it gets stopped with a PermissionError. That's like error code 32 or WinError 5 on Windows. The system does this on purpose to protect the file while it's in use.

Even if you try to delete the file yourself with your mouse, Windows shows a message saying "close the file first." This is normal protection in Windows and other operating systems, as confirmed by Python guides and Microsoft info.

docs.title: Removing files in a different location:
